Notes: The regeneration of Basing View is being actively pursued by the borough council. This is reflected in Local Plan policy SS8 which supports the redevelopment of the area for a mix of uses including a residential component of approximately 300 units. The site is in a suitable location for housing development lying in a highly accessible location with good access to public transport interchanges town centre facilities and employment opportunities. The Council has recently published the Basing View Masterplan which includes provision for residential development. The site plan shows the whole of Basing View reflecting the local plan allocation. The precise location of the residential element will be determined through site masterplanning.
OwnershipStatus: owned by a public authority

Notes: The site is a SHELAA site (BAS012) which falls within the built up area of Basingstoke and within the SPB in an area of predominantly residential development in close proximity to the town. The current use as a police station is due to cease (as part of the wider review of Hampshire Constabulary sites) and the site is currently being marketed for redevelopment. An applicaton was submited in Feburary 2019 (19/00436/FUL) for 55 retirements apartments. The application was refused and turned away at appeal due to insufficient information to validate. Another application for 56 returment appartments (19/01822/FUL was refused by the council in February 2020 with an appeal was later allowed in June 2021 for 56 retirement apartments
OwnershipStatus: not owned by a public authority

Notes: Consent was originally granted on the wider site for the demolition of the Former Newman Bassett House building and a replacement smaller ‘respite unit’ which has now been completed. (Hindson House).Therefore, this retains the facility and service use and frees up the remainder of the land for residential redevelopment. The land is vacant but not currently available as it is being used as a temporary construction compound the requirement for which is due to cease in late 2018. Afterwhich HCC confirm that they intend to apply for planning permission for residential development. The site has been removed as it has been proposed as a wider redevelopment scheme with the fort hill site which now includes this land.
OwnershipStatus: owned by a public authority
SiteNameAddress: Land At Former Newman Bassett House Basingstoke

Notes: The site is the remainder of a larger scheme for tied staff accommodation at Cheam Hawtreys School (BDB/63103, approved 2006). The school has confirmed, through the site monitoring consultation, that whilst the site will be delivered in due course, at present they have no intention to build out the remaining 6 units within the plan period. The site has therefore been phased beyond the plan period and its future delivery will continue to be reviewed through the annual monitoring process.
OwnershipStatus: not owned by a public authority

Notes: The site is allocated for approximately 15 dwellings in the Whitchurch Neighbourhood Plan (Policy HA1) which was made in October 2017 . The brownfield site is currently in use as a police station and is therefore not currently available. The Police Commissioners have confirmed that this site will cease to be used for its present purpose and will be available for housing development within the Plan Period which ends in 2029.
OwnershipStatus: owned by a public authority

Notes: The site is allocated for approximately 10 dwellings in the Whitchurch Neighbourhood Plan (Policy HA3) which was made in October 2017 . The brownfield site is currently in use as a car centre and is therefore not currently available. However the owners have confirmed their intention to redevelop the site for housings over the Local Plan period which runs to 2029.
OwnershipStatus: not owned by a public authority

Notes: The site has been promoted for development through the council's Call for Sites in 2019, with a larger area subsequently promoted in 2021 (5 October) and the council consider this site to be potentially developable for 500 dwellings within a 5-9 year time period, and a further 500 units after this period. While the previous version of the submission was suitable for residential development (as it involved no loss of retail), the current proposal would involve loss of retail and is hence not currently considered suitable for residential. This issue will be considered via the Local Plan Update and further work on the town centre masterplan.
OwnershipStatus: owned by a public authority

Notes: The site has been promoted for development through the council's Call for Sites in 2019 by HCC. The site is considered to be potentially developable for 123 dwellings (net) within a 5-8 year time period and now encompasses a larger area and includes Newman Bassett House (referred to above).

SiteNameAddress: Former Fort Hill Community School Regeneration
